Zora Neale Hurston: Crash Course Black A.comment_text: Celebrating Black excellence>>>>>>>>
we read zora neale hurston in one of my first american lit lectures ( i study in germany), and it was mindblowing to me. This series is such a gift and so important! <3
I'm going to look her up. Thanks.

So grateful to see the intricate simplicity of Crash Course History applied specifically to Black History. The Chanel has the capacity of taking diverse and complex topics and present them in a way that hits the integral points and leaves the viewer wanting more.
Thank you, Alice Walker
Dope
Never realized the Green Brothers were behind this channel.
I had not heard of this author even though I took an African American Literature class in college that covered a lot of content!
What an incredible woman!
Their Eyes Were Watching God is one of those books I read every so often and it’s that time again ❤️ thank you for this video.

Zora Neale Hurston is my FAVORITE author of all time. She is unapologetically herself, and is full of light and life. I can never speak to the Black experience and those struggles, but I admire her for so much for her strength and determination to be both Black and a Woman during a time where so many wanted her to just be one or the other.
She is my favorite part of the Harlem Renaissance and I will continue to try to teach her in every English class I possibly can because she is the embodiment of what it means to be an author in the United States.
Well done, as always.
Thank you for this! I will certainly read a ZN Hurston novel asap!
my sister is named after her
I love her writing so much!

I've been trying to find and read more classic or influential books by black authors and woman authors, as a white male who loves classic and important literature and desires to read all sorts of authors, not just other white males, and in classic literature it is nearly all white dudes without few exceptions. I saw their eyes were watching god in a used bookstore. being familiar with the author's name, but not exactly sure why, I took a chance on it. i had no idea that it was her most important work, and a very important work in general, which I am learning now, I am very much looking forward to reading it.
Their Eyes Were Watching God is one of my absolute favorite American novels. So happy to have this video to point to for info on this amazing woman.
Right on.

I was introduced to Hurston in American Women's Fiction in college.  We study her work along side Ann Petry and Nella Larsen, all of which were amazing but still died in obscurity.  It is a shame they never knew influences of their works.
“She didn't read books so she didn't know that she was the world and the heavens boiled down to a drop.” ― Zora Neale Hurston, Their Eyes Were Watching God.

"Ships at a distance have every man's wish on board. For some they come in with the tide. For others they sail forever on the horizon, never out of sight, never landing until the Watcher turns his eyes away in resignation, his dreams mocked to death by Time. That is the life of men."  This speaks to me, however 'man' centric.  Thank you Zora.  Your words will live forever.
Another great video. Thanks!
I always enjoy listening to episodes on the Harlem Renaissance and people from the Harlem Renaissance. thank you

glad to see Barracoon mentioned.  its depiction of how female Dahomey warriors were deployed in the slaughter & enslavement of Cudjo's village is at first shocking & then logical when you consider their intent.
This series continues to get better and better by the episode. Thank you for shedding a light on those who sometimes never get the shine they deserve. 😌

i just read a book about the history of anthropology centred on Franz Boas and his students, and Zora Neale Hurston featured prominently in it! It’s fascinating to get this more literary perspective right after. Now I’m definitely putting her on my reading list!

I read TEWWG with my AP Lang & Comp class last year and I will never forget how my teacher said, tiredly, that basically all we read is "dead old white men" (it became an inside joke for all of us) for literary merit books deemed AP Level, but she wanted to include some books that had authors who were more diverse and a little more modern and I absolutely loved reading the book and getting the perspective on independence and the liberation of Janie and Zora using her character as a kind of self insert with the many experiences shared between them. I sent this to my teacher from last year, I hope she can share this video and many others can spread her legacy.
I just read Their Eyes Were Watching God a week ago and have eagerly awaited this episode❤️
What an amazing video Thank you so much! Hurston is such a treasure!
Thank you for another rich video. Happy new year to you and the team.
this is one of the best crash courses ever..........!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!
Thank you!!!

I like how Hurston has this uniquely creative spirit and mindset to go beyond the common things that a black person was during her time. I like that. Someone who is able to create a story and break stereotypes of a certain ethnic group rather than adding any type of social issue or stereotype into their stories.
One of my all-time favorite authors in America
My favorite book! Thank you crash course!
God bless her. May she sleep in peace amongst the ancestors

Another great Video! 
I love that you don't present a one-sided story but talk both about the horrible struggles and the fantastic beauty of the Black experience. It shows that this history is not only about historical and political trends but about humanity and the lives of everyday people.

I read "Their Eyes Were Watching God" in 1993 while in college. It was the first time I read a full novel written by an African American author. As a French-Canadian student who hadn't read many non-québécois authors, it was revealing and mind-blowing. Thank you  for this episode!
Fantastic and lovely presentation Friend obrigado friend
Thank you Crash Course.  ZORA is one of my favorites, thanks to Alice Walker who is also one of my favorite writers.  Thank you and please do more of what you do for us.  We need it.
Recent upload in the main page. That's unusual thing of YouTube to do.
